awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Correlated States in Twisted Hetero-bilayer Transition Metal Dichalcogenides
awd_abstract_narration:
Nontechnical Abstract: 
In conventional materials, electrons travel in the periodic arrays of atoms without "talking" (interacting) to each other. When two monolayers of atomically thin materials, also knowns as two-dimensional (2D) materials, are stacked together with a well-controlled twist angle between these two layers, they form a new periodic structure with interesting properties. In this collaborative project, the PIs investigate these 2D materials to gain knowledge that could enable transformative technology innovations such as high-temperature superconductivity, quantum electronics and optoelectronics. This project integrates an education component to train students and build a strong workforce for quantum science and technologies. Under-represented groups are particularly encouraged and included in the education programs.

Technical Abstract: 
Correlated states such as Mott insulators and Wigner crystals remain intriguing subjects of physics. More recently, twisted hetero-bilayer transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) have emerged as a new platform with even more enhanced correlation strength, and their strong spin-orbit coupling and presence of bandgaps provide new avenues to explore spin-related physics and optoelectronics in correlated states. In this collaborative proposal, the PIs explore the moiré superlattices formed by twisted hetero-bilayer TMDs. The research plan includes two main thrusts. Thrust I is to characterize the interaction strength of the correlated states and study its relationship with moiré structure parameters and external controls to manipulate the correlated states. Thrust II is to explore new correlated states arising from interactions with other electronic phases, such as the interplay of correlated states with Landau levels, the effect of strong correlation on valley physics and excitonic physics of the moiré superlattice, and other types of new states that could possibly arise in this strongly interacting system. The collaborative project trains graduate and undergraduate students are trained for future placement in quantum science and technologies. The project also creates research modules for outreach to K-12 students and actively involves under-represented groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Over the course of this project, we have extensively studied the correlated physics in the TMDC moire heterojunction, with a focus on the WS2/WSe2 moire heterojunction. The completion of this project significantly advances our understanding of correlated physics in TMDC moire heterojunction, and it also guides us on how to use the understanding to engineer new quantum states. The results from this project have been published in a number of prestigious peer-reviewed journals and also reported by various news channels. This project also contributed significantly to the training of graduate students, undergraduate students, and K-12 students.

Intellectual merits

During the course of this project, we have identified correlated states at fractional fillings of WSe2/WS2 through a photoluminescence spectroscopy study. We have demonstrated layer tunability of moire exciton and correlated states (Nature Comm. 2022). We have engineered and studied a new excitonic insulator state by engineering the electron correlation in a multilayer TMDC moire superlattice (Nature Physics 2022).  We have demonstrated the engineering of quadrupolar excitons in a trilayer moire heterojunction and studied how it interacts with correlated electrons (Nature Comm. 2023). We have revealed and studied moire exciton hybridization in a multilayer TMDC moire heterojunction (Nature Comm. 2023). We have also revealed and investigated an excitonic Mott insulator state in WSe2/WS2 moire heterojunction (Nature Physics 2024). This project also help us to finish a peer-reviewed review paper on the correlated physics in TMDC moire superlattice (Nature Comm. 2023).

A full list of the publications in peer-reviewed journals is included at the end of the outcome report.

Broader impacts

Our study supported by this project significantly has advanced our understanding of correlated physics, inspiring many to pursue this research direction.  Our results have been reported by many channels such as Nature Physics ( www.nature.com/articles/s41567-023-02274-2) and  Physics.org ( https://phys.org/news/2022-10-tune-moir-excitons-tmdc-superlattices.html), (https://phys.org/news/2022-09-evidence-excitonic-insulators-moir-superlattices.html).

This project has partially supported two graduate students to finish their PhD degree and contributed to other graduate training. This project has also help trained undergraduate researchers and contributed to outreach activities for K-12 students.
